Crosstacean Heavy Crossbow (Very Rare).name: Crosstacean Heavy Crossbow (Very Rare)
Crosstacean Heavy Crossbow (Very Rare).description:
Weapon, very rare (requires attunement)
Martial weapon, ranged weapon 18 lb.
[[/r 1d10]] piercing - ammunition (100/400 ft.), heavy, loading, two-handed

The longevity of lobsters is well known. Using biomancy, this phenomenon can be reversed, resulting in a weapon that can magically age and necrose a target.

This weapon deals an extra [[/r 1d8]] necrotic damage to any target it hits.

The Seize. While holding this weapon, you can use a bonus action to enhance one piece of loaded ammunition with debilitating, arthritic energy that causes the target's joints to seize solid. If the next attack you make with the weapon hits, the target must succeed on a DC 16 Constitution saving throw or become restrained until the end of your next turn. If the target fails by 5 or more, it is paralyzed instead of restrained. After this property has been used, roll a [[/r d6]]. On a 1, the lobster's colour fades to grey, and this property can't be used again until the next dawn.

Range. A weapon that can be used to make a ranged attack has a range shown in parentheses after the ammunition or thrown property. The range lists two numbers. The first is the weapon's normal range in feet, and the second indicates the weapon's maximum range. When attacking a target beyond normal range, you have disadvantage on the attack roll. You can't attack a target beyond the weapon's long range.

Ammunition. You can use a weapon that has the ammunition property to make a ranged attack only if you have ammunition to fire from the weapon. Each time you attack with the weapon, you expend one piece of ammunition. Drawing the ammunition from a quiver, case, or other container is part of the attack. Loading a one-handed weapon requires a free hand. At the end of the battle, you can recover half your expended ammunition by taking a minute to search the battlefield.

If you use a weapon that has the ammunition property to make a melee attack, you treat the weapon as an improvised weapon. A sling must be loaded to deal any damage when used in this way.

Heavy. Creatures that are Small or Tiny have disadvantage on attack rolls with heavy weapons. A heavy weapon's size and bulk make it too large for a Small or Tiny creature to use effectively.

Loading. Because of the time required to load this weapon, you can fire only one piece of ammunition from it when you use an action, bonus action, or reaction to fire it, regardless of the number of attacks you can normally make.

Two-Handed. This weapon requires two hands to use. This property is relevant only when you attack with the weapon, not when you simply hold it.

Seashell Chakram (Uncommon).name: Seashell Chakram (Uncommon)
Seashell Chakram (Uncommon).description:
Weapon, uncommon
Martial weapon, melee weapon [[/r 1d4]] slashing - finesse, light, thrown (30/90 ft.), Thrown Versatility ([[/r 1d6]])

Fashioned from the pearlescent bloodshells of the Scarlet Reef, this weapon of the coralborn is enchanted to be especially hydrodynamic underwater.

You gain a +1 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with this magic weapon while underwater.

Hydrodynamic. Attacking while underwater doesn't impose disadvantage on attack rolls you make with this weapon.

Chakrams are martial melee weapons, consisting of a circular blade with a sharp outer edge. They deal [[/r 1d4]] slashing damage on a hit, can count as a monk weapon, and have the Light, Finesse, Thrown (range 30/90), and Thrown Versatility ([[/r 1d6]]) properties.

Finesse. When making an attack with a finesse weapon, you use your choice of your Strength or Dexterity modifier for the attack and damage rolls. You must use the same modifier for both rolls.

Light. A light weapon is small and easy to handle, making it ideal for use when fighting with two weapons.

Thrown. If a weapon has the thrown property, you can throw the weapon to make a ranged attack. If the weapon is a melee weapon, you use the same ability modifier for that attack roll and damage roll that you would use for a melee attack with the weapon. For example, if you throw a handaxe, you use your Strength, but if you throw a dagger, you can use either your Strength or your Dexterity, since the dagger has the finesse property.

Thrown Versatility. This weapon is better used for thrown ranged weapon attacks than for melee weapon attacks. A damage value in parentheses appears with the property—the damage when the weapon is used to make a ranged weapon attack.

Seashell Tetherhook (Uncommon).name: Seashell Tetherhook (Uncommon)
Seashell Tetherhook (Uncommon).description:
Weapon, uncommon
Martial weapon, melee weapon [[/r 1d8]] piercing - reach, special, two-handed

Fashioned from the pearlescent bloodshells of the Scarlet Reef, this weapon of the coralborn is enchanted to be especially hydrodynamic underwater.

You gain a +1 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with this magic weapon while underwater.

Hydrodynamic. Attacking while underwater doesn't impose disadvantage on attack rolls you make with this weapon.

A tetherhook is a martial melee weapon with the Reach, Two-handed, and Special: Hookpull properties. It is comprised of a hook attached to a chain or strap and deals [[/r 1d8]] piercing damage on a hit.

Special: Hookpull. As a bonus action immediately after you hit a target no more than one size larger than you with an attack using the tetherhook, you can attempt to hook the target using the tetherhook’s reach. Make a Strength (Athletics) check contested by the target’s Strength (Athletics) or Dexterity (Acrobatics) check (the target chooses the ability to use). If you succeed, the target is hooked and can’t move further away from you. A hooked creature is no longer hooked if you release the tether with both hands, but only one hand is required to keep a creature hooked. A hooked creature can use its action to escape. To do so, it must succeed on a Strength (Athletics) or Dexterity (Acrobatics) check contested by your Strength (Athletics) check.

As part of the bonus action to hook the target, and as a bonus action on any of your subsequent turns while it remains hooked, you can pull the target 5 feet closer to you, as long as it isn’t fixed in place and it weighs less than your push, drag, or lift capacity.

Reach. This weapon adds 5 feet to your reach when you attack with it. This property also determines your reach for opportunity attacks with a reach weapon.

Two-Handed. This weapon requires two hands to use. This property is relevant only when you attack with the weapon, not when you simply hold it.

Seashell Revolver (Common).name: Seashell Revolver (Common)
Seashell Revolver (Common).description:
Weapon, common
Firearm, martial weapon, ranged weapon [[/r 1d10]] piercing - ammunition (60/240 ft.), Loud (500), Reload (6)

Fashioned from the pearlescent bloodshells of the Scarlet Reef, this weapon of the coralborn is enchanted to be especially hydrodynamic underwater.

Hydrodynamic. Attacking while underwater doesn't impose disadvantage on attack rolls you make with this weapon.

A small, personal firearm with a rotating barrel and accuracy-enhancing rifling that deals [[/r 1d10]] piercing damage on a hit. It has the Ammunition (range 60/240), Loud (500), Reload (6) properties.

Extra Reloads. More expensive models of magitech firearms have a self-reloading mechanism that harnesses the arcanomagnetic engine to re-cock the weapon. If you wish, you can increase the magazine capacity of a magitech firearm up to a maximum of 6, ensuring that the price increases proportionally. For example, a pistol typically costs 200 gp and has reload (2). If you increased this to reload (6), you would multiply the price by 3 for a new cost of 600 gp.

Range. A weapon that can be used to make a ranged attack has a range shown in parentheses after the ammunition or thrown property. The range lists two numbers. The first is the weapon's normal range in feet, and the second indicates the weapon's maximum range. When attacking a target beyond normal range, you have disadvantage on the attack roll. You can't attack a target beyond the weapon's long range.

Ammunition. You can use a weapon that has the ammunition property to make a ranged attack only if you have ammunition to fire from the weapon. Each time you attack with the weapon, you expend one piece of ammunition. Drawing the ammunition from a quiver, case, or other container is part of the attack. Loading a one-handed weapon requires a free hand. At the end of the battle, you can recover half your expended ammunition by taking a minute to search the battlefield.

If you use a weapon that has the ammunition property to make a melee attack, you treat the weapon as an improvised weapon. A sling must be loaded to deal any damage when used in this way.

Loud (X). The sound of the weapon discharging alerts all hearing creatures within a number of feet as specified by the number in parentheses after the loud property. This range is doubled in echoey locations, such as cave systems, and where sound travels faster, such as underwater.

Reload (X). A limited number of shots, specified by the number in parentheses after the reload property, can be made with this weapon. A character must then reload it using an action.

Allure (Very Rare).name: Allure (Very Rare)
Allure (Very Rare).description:
Wondrous item, very rare (requires attunement)

As the saying goes: "Lights on the surface serve a purpose. Lights in the deep lure then reap." This magical headpiece, while not the most attractive, has a certain allure.

While wearing this circlet, you can cast the @Compendium[dnd5e.spells.CAxSzHWizrafT033]{Dancing Lights} cantrip. When you cast @Compendium[dnd5e.spells.CAxSzHWizrafT033]{Dancing Lights}, the spell doesn’t require concentration but ends if you cast it again, and you can choose any number of the lights to shed bright light in a 10-foot radius and dim light for an additional 10 feet.

Lure. While wearing this circlet, you can use your action to briefly create an alluring pattern of glowing lights around you. Each creature within 20 feet of you who sees the pattern must make a DC 16 Wisdom saving throw. On a failed save, the creature becomes charmed until the start of your next turn. While charmed in this way, the creature is incapacitated and must use all its movement to approach you. If a creature ends its movement within 5 feet of you, it reaches towards your circlet. As a reaction, you can cause the circlet to bite down on the creature, dealing [[/r 1d6]] piercing damage and [[/r 4d6]] poison damage to it. Once this property of the circlet has been used twice, it can't be used again until the next dawn.

Seashell Heavy Tommybow (Common).description:

Martial weapon, ranged weapon 18 lb.

Hydrodynamic. Attacking while underwater doesn't impose disadvantage on attack rolls you make with this weapon.

Tommybows are repeating crossbows that mirror the three types of normal crossbows: hand, heavy, and light. They are composed of vertically-stacked bows upon a crossbow's chassis, an unwieldy arrangement that reduces their effective range in comparison to their crossbow counterparts.

Tommybows replace the loading property of their crossbow counterpart with the reload property. The cost of the item is proportional to the amount of ammunition it can hold (the value in parentheses), with the maximum reload (6) tommybow costing six times its crossbow counterpart's price.

Coral Crusher Light Hammer (Uncommon).name: Coral Crusher Light Hammer (Uncommon)
Coral Crusher Light Hammer (Uncommon).description:
Weapon, uncommon
Simple weapon, melee weapon 2 lb.
[[/r 1d4]] bludgeoning - light, thrown (20/60 ft.)

Through biomantic infusions, the coral that comprises this weapon can grow rapidly, quickly replenishing itself under the right conditions. Coralborn have mixed feelings towards such magic weapons. Some believe that it is sacrilege to damage a reef, while others argue that the foes these weapons shred are prevented from doing any harm to anything, including reefs. The jury is still out. These heavy weapons, with their fragile, spiky exteriors, send splinters of coral flying, hurting all creatures within close proximity. Safety glasses are recommended.

Shred. Once on each of your turns when you hit a target with a melee attack using this weapon, you can cause coral shrapnel to burst out. The target and each creature within 5 feet of it must succeed on a DC 13 Dexterity saving throw or take piercing damage equal to one of the weapon's damage dice. You have advantage on this saving throw.

Hydrodynamic. Attacking while underwater doesn't impose disadvantage on attack rolls you make with this weapon.

Light. A light weapon is small and easy to handle, making it ideal for use when fighting with two weapons.

Martial weapon, melee weapon 500 lb.
[[/r 1d8]] slashing - versatile ([[/r 1d10]])

With the sound of waves crashing violently against a rocky cliff, the sword's blade rushes forth like the tide, inevitable and unstoppable. Not even tempered steel can resist its edge, which slices through obstacles like a hot knife through melted butter.

This item appears to be a sword hilt stylized with tentacles. While grasping the hilt, you can use a bonus action to cause a blade of rushing water to spring forth, or make it disappear. While the blade exists, this magic longsword has the finesse property. If you are proficient with shortswords or longswords, you are proficient with the tidecutter.

Water Lash. As an action, you can cause the sword's blade to elongate into a lash and make a melee weapon attack using it against a target within 20 feet of you. On a hit, if the target is a Medium or smaller creature or an object that weighs 500 pounds or less, you can pull it up to 15 feet towards you. If the target is a fixed object or a Huge or larger creature, you can pull yourself up to 15 feet towards the target.

Waterborne. When submerged in water, this longsword gains the reach property and the range of the Water Lash property increases to 30 feet.

Hydrodynamic. Attacking while underwater doesn't impose disadvantage on attack rolls you make with this weapon.

Versatile. This weapon can be used with one or two hands. A damage value in parentheses appears with the property—the damage when the weapon is used with two hands to make a melee attack.

Seashell Lance (Uncommon).name: Seashell Lance (Uncommon)
Seashell Lance (Uncommon).description:
Weapon, uncommon
Martial weapon, melee weapon 6 lb.
[[/r 1d12]] piercing - reach, special

Fashioned from the pearlescent bloodshells of the Scarlet Reef, this weapon of the coralborn is enchanted to be especially hydrodynamic underwater.

You gain a +1 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with this magic weapon while underwater.

Hydrodynamic. Attacking while underwater doesn't impose disadvantage on attack rolls you make with this weapon.

Special. You have disadvantage when you use a lance to attack a target within 5 feet of you. Also, a lance requires two hands to wield when you aren't mounted.

Reach. This weapon adds 5 feet to your reach when you attack with it. This property also determines your reach for opportunity attacks with a reach weapon.

Seashell Pistol (Uncommon).name: Seashell Pistol (Uncommon)
Seashell Pistol (Uncommon).description:
Weapon, uncommon
Firearm, martial weapon, ranged weapon [[/r 1d8]] piercing - ammunition (40/120 ft.), Loud (500), Reload (2)

Fashioned from the pearlescent bloodshells of the Scarlet Reef, this weapon of the coralborn is enchanted to be especially hydrodynamic underwater.

You gain a +1 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with this magic weapon while underwater.

Hydrodynamic. Attacking while underwater doesn't impose disadvantage on attack rolls you make with this weapon.

A small, personal, double-barreled firearm that deals [[/r 1d8]] piercing damage on a hit. It has the Ammunition (range 40/120), Loud (500), Reload (2) properties.

Extra Reloads. More expensive models of magitech firearms have a self-reloading mechanism that harnesses the arcanomagnetic engine to re-cock the weapon. If you wish, you can increase the magazine capacity of a magitech firearm up to a maximum of 6, ensuring that the price increases proportionally. For example, a pistol typically costs 200 gp and has reload (2). If you increased this to reload (6), you would multiply the price by 3 for a new cost of 600 gp.

Range. A weapon that can be used to make a ranged attack has a range shown in parentheses after the ammunition or thrown property. The range lists two numbers. The first is the weapon's normal range in feet, and the second indicates the weapon's maximum range. When attacking a target beyond normal range, you have disadvantage on the attack roll. You can't attack a target beyond the weapon's long range.

Ammunition. You can use a weapon that has the ammunition property to make a ranged attack only if you have ammunition to fire from the weapon. Each time you attack with the weapon, you expend one piece of ammunition. Drawing the ammunition from a quiver, case, or other container is part of the attack. Loading a one-handed weapon requires a free hand. At the end of the battle, you can recover half your expended ammunition by taking a minute to search the battlefield.

If you use a weapon that has the ammunition property to make a melee attack, you treat the weapon as an improvised weapon. A sling must be loaded to deal any damage when used in this way.

Loud (X). The sound of the weapon discharging alerts all hearing creatures within a number of feet as specified by the number in parentheses after the loud property. This range is doubled in echoey locations, such as cave systems, and where sound travels faster, such as underwater.

Reload (X). A limited number of shots, specified by the number in parentheses after the reload property, can be made with this weapon. A character must then reload it using an action.

Sharktooth Greatsword (Very Rare).name: Sharktooth Greatsword (Very Rare)
Sharktooth Greatsword (Very Rare).description:
Weapon, very rare (requires attunement)

Martial weapon, melee weapon 6 lb.
[[/r 2d6]] slashing - heavy, two-handed

Fashioned especially for the Hammerhead Knight, this blade caused its victims to bleed, allowing the knight, with its superior sense of smell, to track a would-be assassin back to its lair.

You gain a +2 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with this magic weapon.

Maim. Once on each of your turns when you hit a creature with an attack roll using this weapon, you can speak its command word, causing its teeth-like protrusions to rip through the target. Roll a [[/r d4]] and consult the following table to determine the effect:

[[/r d4]]Effect
1No additional effect.
2Hamstring. The creature’s speed is reduced to 0 feet until the end of its next turn.
3Rend. The creature has disadvantage on attack rolls until the end of its next turn.
4Sever. If the creature has blood, it begins bleeding for 1 minute. Each time it takes bludgeoning, piercing, or slashing damage while bleeding, it takes an extra [[/r 1d4]] necrotic damage. The target or a creature within reach can use an action to make a DC 16 Wisdom (Medicine) check, stopping the bleeding on a success.

Hydrodynamic. Attacking while underwater doesn't impose disadvantage on attack rolls you make with this weapon.

Heavy. Creatures that are Small or Tiny have disadvantage on attack rolls with heavy weapons. A heavy weapon's size and bulk make it too large for a Small or Tiny creature to use effectively.

Two-Handed. This weapon requires two hands to use. This property is relevant only when you attack with the weapon, not when you simply hold it.

Crosstacean Light Tommybow (Very Rare).name: Crosstacean Light Tommybow (Very Rare)
Crosstacean Light Tommybow (Very Rare).description:
Weapon, very rare (requires attunement)
Simple weapon, ranged weapon 5 lb.
[[/r 1d8]] piercing - ammunition (80/160 ft.), Reload (2), two-handed

The longevity of lobsters is well known. Using biomancy, this phenomenon can be reversed, resulting in a weapon that can magically age and necrose a target.

This weapon deals an extra [[/r 1d8]] necrotic damage to any target it hits.

The Seize. While holding this weapon, you can use a bonus action to enhance one piece of loaded ammunition with debilitating, arthritic energy that causes the target's joints to seize solid. If the next attack you make with the weapon hits, the target must succeed on a DC 16 Constitution saving throw or become restrained until the end of your next turn. If the target fails by 5 or more, it is paralyzed instead of restrained. After this property has been used, roll a [[/r d6]]. On a 1, the lobster's colour fades to grey, and this property can't be used again until the next dawn.

Tommybows are repeating crossbows that mirror the three types of normal crossbows: hand, heavy, and light. They are composed of vertically-stacked bows upon a crossbow's chassis, an unwieldy arrangement that reduces their effective range in comparison to their crossbow counterparts.

Tommybows replace the loading property of their crossbow counterpart with the reload property. The cost of the item is proportional to the amount of ammunition it can hold (the value in parentheses), with the maximum reload (6) tommybow costing six times its crossbow counterpart's price.

Tommybow Cost
Base CrossbowReload (2)Reload (3)Reload (4)Reload (5)Reload (6)
Light Crossbow50 gp75 gp100 gp125 gp150 gp

The first is the weapon's normal range in feet, and the second indicates the weapon's maximum range. When attacking a target beyond normal range, you have disadvantage on the attack roll. You can't attack a target beyond the weapon's long range.

Ammunition. You can use a weapon that has the ammunition property to make a ranged attack only if you have ammunition to fire from the weapon. Each time you attack with the weapon, you expend one piece of ammunition. Drawing the ammunition from a quiver, case, or other container is part of the attack. Loading a one-handed weapon requires a free hand. At the end of the battle, you can recover half your expended ammunition by taking a minute to search the battlefield.

If you use a weapon that has the ammunition property to make a melee attack, you treat the weapon as an improvised weapon. A sling must be loaded to deal any damage when used in this way.

Reload (X). A limited number of shots, specified by the number in parentheses after the reload property, can be made with this weapon. A character must then reload it using an action.

Two-Handed. This weapon requires two hands to use. This property is relevant only when you attack with the weapon, not when you simply hold it.

Coral Crusher Greatclub (Uncommon).name: Coral Crusher Greatclub (Uncommon)
Coral Crusher Greatclub (Uncommon).description:
Weapon, uncommon
Simple weapon, melee weapon 10 lb.
[[/r 1d8]] bludgeoning - two-handed

Through biomantic infusions, the coral that comprises this weapon can grow rapidly, quickly replenishing itself under the right conditions. Coralborn have mixed feelings towards such magic weapons. Some believe that it is sacrilege to damage a reef, while others argue that the foes these weapons shred are prevented from doing any harm to anything, including reefs. The jury is still out. These heavy weapons, with their fragile, spiky exteriors, send splinters of coral flying, hurting all creatures within close proximity. Safety glasses are recommended.

Shred. Once on each of your turns when you hit a target with a melee attack using this weapon, you can cause coral shrapnel to burst out. The target and each creature within 5 feet of it must succeed on a DC 13 Dexterity saving throw or take piercing damage equal to one of the weapon's damage dice. You have advantage on this saving throw.

Hydrodynamic. Attacking while underwater doesn't impose disadvantage on attack rolls you make with this weapon.

Two-Handed. This weapon requires two hands to use. This property is relevant only when you attack with the weapon, not when you simply hold it.

Seashell Scimitar (Common).name: Seashell Scimitar (Common)
Seashell Scimitar (Common).description:
Weapon, common
Martial weapon, melee weapon 3 lb.
[[/r 1d6]] slashing - finesse, light

Fashioned from the pearlescent bloodshells of the Scarlet Reef, this weapon of the coralborn is enchanted to be especially hydrodynamic underwater.

Hydrodynamic. Attacking while underwater doesn't impose disadvantage on attack rolls you make with this weapon.

Finesse. When making an attack with a finesse weapon, you use your choice of your Strength or Dexterity modifier for the attack and damage rolls. You must use the same modifier for both rolls.

Light. A light weapon is small and easy to handle, making it ideal for use when fighting with two weapons.

Cloak of the Cnidaran (Uncommon).name: Cloak of the Cnidaran (Uncommon)
Cloak of the Cnidaran (Uncommon).description:
Wondrous item, uncommon (requires attunement)

Made of magical cnidaran shimmerweave, this cloak shifts its hue with the emotions of its attuned wearer. The Deep King's court jester used to wear one such raiment, making his acrobatic and charismatic displays all the more entertaining.

Prismatic Shimmer. As an action while wearing this cloak, you can cause it to shimmer in a pleasing and distracting array of colours for 10 minutes. For the duration, you have advantage on Deception, Performance, and Persuasion checks. Once this property of the cloak has been used, it can't be used again until the next dawn.

Nematocyst Fibres. As an action while wearing this cloak, you can cause its fibres to become aggressive for 1 minute. The cloak shimmers in shades of red and mauve, giving you advantage on Intimidation checks against creatures that can see you. As part of the action to activate the fibres, and as an action on subsequent turns, you can cause the cloak's filaments to brush against a creature within 10 feet of you. The target must succeed on a DC 1313 Constitution saving throw or become poisoned until the start of your next turn. Until this poison ends, the target is incapacitated. After a creature succeeds on this saving throw, it is immune to the effects of the cloak for the next 24 hours. Once this property of the cloak has been used, it can't be used again until the next dawn.

Seashell Battleaxe (Common).description:
Weapon, common
Martial weapon, melee weapon 4 lb.
[[/r 1d8]] slashing - versatile ([[/r 1d10]])

Fashioned from the pearlescent bloodshells of the Scarlet Reef, this weapon of the coralborn is enchanted to be especially hydrodynamic underwater.

Hydrodynamic. Attacking while underwater doesn't impose disadvantage on attack rolls you make with this weapon.

Versatile. This weapon can be used with one or two hands. A damage value in parentheses appears with the property—the damage when the weapon is used with two hands to make a melee attack.

Crosstacean Hand Tommybow (Uncommon).name: Crosstacean Hand Tommybow (Uncommon)
Crosstacean Hand Tommybow (Uncommon).description:
Weapon, uncommon (requires attunement)
Martial weapon, ranged weapon 3 lb.
[[/r 1d6]] piercing - ammunition (30/60 ft.), Reload (2)

The longevity of lobsters is well known. Using biomancy, this phenomenon can be reversed, resulting in a weapon that can magically age and necrose a target.

This weapon deals an extra [[/r 1d4]] necrotic damage to any target it hits.

The Seize. While holding this weapon, you can use a bonus action to enhance one piece of loaded ammunition with debilitating, arthritic energy that causes the target's joints to seize solid. If the next attack you make with the weapon hits, the target must succeed on a DC 13 Constitution saving throw or become restrained until the end of your next turn. If the target fails by 5 or more, it is paralyzed instead of restrained. After this property has been used, roll a [[/r d6]]. On a 3 or lower, the lobster's colour fades to grey, and this property can't be used again until the next dawn.

Tommybows are repeating crossbows that mirror the three types of normal crossbows: hand, heavy, and light. They are composed of vertically-stacked bows upon a crossbow's chassis, an unwieldy arrangement that reduces their effective range in comparison to their crossbow counterparts.

Tommybows replace the loading property of their crossbow counterpart with the reload property. The cost of the item is proportional to the amount of ammunition it can hold (the value in parentheses), with the maximum reload (6) tommybow costing six times its crossbow counterpart's price.

Tommybow Cost
Base CrossbowReload (2)Reload (3)Reload (4)Reload (5)Reload (6)
Hand Crossbow150 gp225 gp300 gp375 gp450 gp

Range. A weapon that can be used to make a ranged attack has a range shown in parentheses after the ammunition or thrown property. The range lists two numbers. The first is the weapon's normal range in feet, and the second indicates the weapon's maximum range. When attacking a target beyond normal range, you have disadvantage on the attack roll. You can't attack a target beyond the weapon's long range.

Reload (X). A limited number of shots, specified by the number in parentheses after the reload property, can be made with this weapon. A character must then reload it using an action.

Ammunition. You can use a weapon that has the ammunition property to make a ranged attack only if you have ammunition to fire from the weapon. Each time you attack with the weapon, you expend one piece of ammunition. Drawing the ammunition from a quiver, case, or other container is part of the attack. Loading a one-handed weapon requires a free hand. At the end of the battle, you can recover half your expended ammunition by taking a minute to search the battlefield.

If you use a weapon that has the ammunition property to make a melee attack, you treat the weapon as an improvised weapon. A sling must be loaded to deal any damage when used in this way.

Coral Crusher Warhammer (Uncommon).name: Coral Crusher Warhammer (Uncommon)
Coral Crusher Warhammer (Uncommon).description:
Weapon, uncommon
Martial weapon, melee weapon 2 lb.
[[/r 1d8]] bludgeoning - versatile ([[/r 1d10]])

Through biomantic infusions, the coral that comprises this weapon can grow rapidly, quickly replenishing itself under the right conditions. Coralborn have mixed feelings towards such magic weapons. Some believe that it is sacrilege to damage a reef, while others argue that the foes these weapons shred are prevented from doing any harm to anything, including reefs. The jury is still out. These heavy weapons, with their fragile, spiky exteriors, send splinters of coral flying, hurting all creatures within close proximity. Safety glasses are recommended.

Shred. Once on each of your turns when you hit a target with a melee attack using this weapon, you can cause coral shrapnel to burst out. The target and each creature within 5 feet of it must succeed on a DC 13 Dexterity saving throw or take piercing damage equal to one of the weapon's damage dice. You have advantage on this saving throw.

Hydrodynamic. Attacking while underwater doesn't impose disadvantage on attack rolls you make with this weapon.

Versatile. This weapon can be used with one or two hands. A damage value in parentheses appears with the property—the damage when the weapon is used with two hands to make a melee attack.

Seashell Blunderbuss (Common).name: Seashell Blunderbuss (Common)
Seashell Blunderbuss (Common).description:
Weapon, common
Firearm, martial weapon, ranged weapon [[/r 3d4]] piercing - ammunition (20/60 ft.), Loud (1000), Reload (1), two-handed

Fashioned from the pearlescent bloodshells of the Scarlet Reef, this weapon of the coralborn is enchanted to be especially hydrodynamic underwater.

Hydrodynamic. Attacking while underwater doesn't impose disadvantage on attack rolls you make with this weapon.

A high-powered, short range firearm that deals [[/r 3d4]] piercing damage on a hit. It has the Ammunition (range 20/60), Loud (1000), Reload (1), and Two-handed properties.

Extra Reloads. More expensive models of magitech firearms have a self-reloading mechanism that harnesses the arcanomagnetic engine to re-cock the weapon. If you wish, you can increase the magazine capacity of a magitech firearm up to a maximum of 6, ensuring that the price increases proportionally. For example, a pistol typically costs 200 gp and has reload (2). If you increased this to reload (6), you would multiply the price by 3 for a new cost of 600 gp.

Range. A weapon that can be used to make a ranged attack has a range shown in parentheses after the ammunition or thrown property. The range lists two numbers. The first is the weapon's normal range in feet, and the second indicates the weapon's maximum range. When attacking a target beyond normal range, you have disadvantage on the attack roll. You can't attack a target beyond the weapon's long range.

Ammunition. You can use a weapon that has the ammunition property to make a ranged attack only if you have ammunition to fire from the weapon. Each time you attack with the weapon, you expend one piece of ammunition. Drawing the ammunition from a quiver, case, or other container is part of the attack. Loading a one-handed weapon requires a free hand. At the end of the battle, you can recover half your expended ammunition by taking a minute to search the battlefield.

If you use a weapon that has the ammunition property to make a melee attack, you treat the weapon as an improvised weapon. A sling must be loaded to deal any damage when used in this way.

Loud (X). The sound of the weapon discharging alerts all hearing creatures within a number of feet as specified by the number in parentheses after the loud property. This range is doubled in echoey locations, such as cave systems, and where sound travels faster, such as underwater.

Reload (X). A limited number of shots, specified by the number in parentheses after the reload property, can be made with this weapon. A character must then reload it using an action.

Two-Handed. This weapon requires two hands to use. This property is relevant only when you attack with the weapon, not when you simply hold it.

Seashell Nunchaku (Uncommon).name: Seashell Nunchaku (Uncommon)
Seashell Nunchaku (Uncommon).description:
Weapon, uncommon
Martial weapon, melee weapon [[/r 1d6]] bludgeoning - finesse, special, versatile ([[/r 1d8]])

Fashioned from the pearlescent bloodshells of the Scarlet Reef, this weapon of the coralborn is enchanted to be especially hydrodynamic underwater.

You gain a +1 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with this magic weapon while underwater.

Hydrodynamic. Attacking while underwater doesn't impose disadvantage on attack rolls you make with this weapon.

Nunchuks are martial melee weapons composed of two hard batons, usually wood or metal, connected to one another by a short chain. They have the versatile (1d8), finesse, and special (flourish) properties, and deal 1d6 bludgeoning damage on a hit.

Special: Flourish. When you are wielding the nunchaku in two hands and take the Attack action on your turn, you can attempt to flourish with the weapon immediately before you make your first attack. To flourish, make a DC 13 Dexterity check, adding your proficiency bonus if you are proficient with nunchaku. On a success, you gain a +2 bonus to the first attack roll you make this turn. On a failure, you deal bludgeoning damage to yourself equal to your proficiency bonus and gain no bonus from your flourishes this turn.

Finesse. When making an attack with a finesse weapon, you use your choice of your Strength or Dexterity modifier for the attack and damage rolls. You must use the same modifier for both rolls.

Versatile. This weapon can be used with one or two hands. A damage value in parentheses appears with the property—the damage when the weapon is used with two hands to make a melee attack.

Seashell Spiked Cestus (Common).name: Seashell Spiked Cestus (Common)
Seashell Spiked Cestus (Common).description:
Weapon, common
Simple weapon, melee weapon [[/r 1d6]] bludgeoning - alt. [[/r 1d6]], Adaptable (P), attached, pugilist

Fashioned from the pearlescent bloodshells of the Scarlet Reef, this weapon of the coralborn is enchanted to be especially hydrodynamic underwater.

Hydrodynamic. Attacking while underwater doesn't impose disadvantage on attack rolls you make with this weapon.

A spiked cestus is a simple melee weapon worn around the knuckles of one hand that deals [[/r 1d6]] bludgeoning damage on a hit and has the Adaptable (piercing), Attached, and Pugilist properties.

Attached. You can't be disarmed of this weapon, but donning or doffing the weapon takes an action. You can use a hand equipped with this weapon to hold items, but can't attack with the weapon while doing so. Additionally, you have disadvantage on attack rolls using other weapons held in a hand equipped with this weapon and on Sleight of Hand checks using the hand that is equipped with this weapon.

Pugilist. For creatures that roll a die when they make unarmed strikes (such as the monk or tavern brawler fighter), the size of their damage die is increased by one (maximum 1d12) when they make unarmed strikes with a hand equipped with a weapon that has this property.

Adaptable. This weapon can be used with differing techniques, allowing it to deal different types of damage. A damage type in parentheses appears with the property—when a creature makes a weapon attack with this weapon, it can choose either the weapon's normal damage type or this damage type.

Seashell Handaxe (Uncommon).name: Seashell Handaxe (Uncommon)
Seashell Handaxe (Uncommon).description:
Weapon, uncommon
Simple weapon, melee weapon 2 lb.
[[/r 1d6]] slashing - light, thrown (20/60 ft.)

Fashioned from the pearlescent bloodshells of the Scarlet Reef, this weapon of the coralborn is enchanted to be especially hydrodynamic underwater.

You gain a +1 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with this magic weapon while underwater.

Hydrodynamic. Attacking while underwater doesn't impose disadvantage on attack rolls you make with this weapon.

Light. A light weapon is small and easy to handle, making it ideal for use when fighting with two weapons.

Thrown. If a weapon has the thrown property, you can throw the weapon to make a ranged attack. If the weapon is a melee weapon, you use the same ability modifier for that attack roll and damage roll that you would use for a melee attack with the weapon. For example, if you throw a handaxe, you use your Strength, but if you throw a dagger, you can use either your Strength or your Dexterity, since the dagger has the finesse property.

Seashell Twinblade (Common).name: Seashell Twinblade (Common)
Seashell Twinblade (Common).description:
Weapon, common
Martial weapon, melee weapon [[/r 2d4]] slashing - finesse, special, two-handed

Fashioned from the pearlescent bloodshells of the Scarlet Reef, this weapon of the coralborn is enchanted to be especially hydrodynamic underwater.

Hydrodynamic. Attacking while underwater doesn't impose disadvantage on attack rolls you make with this weapon.

Twinblades are martial melee weapons; double-bladed polearms that rely on the user’s dexterity to keep them in constant motion. They deal [[/r 2d4]] slashing damage on a hit and have the Finesse and Two-handed properties. They also have the Special: Whirl property.

Special: Whirl. If you are proficient with the twin-blade, you can use a bonus action to attempt to whirl the weapon. Make a DC 15 Dexterity check. On a success, you gain a +2 bonus to your AC until the start of your next turn, the whirling blades acting as a barrier against attacks. On a failure, that bonus is only a +1.

Finesse. When making an attack with a finesse weapon, you use your choice of your Strength or Dexterity modifier for the attack and damage rolls. You must use the same modifier for both rolls.

Two-Handed. This weapon requires two hands to use. This property is relevant only when you attack with the weapon, not when you simply hold it.

Loading. Because of the time required to load this weapon, you can fire only one piece of ammunition from it when you use an action, bonus action, or reaction to fire it, regardless of the number of attacks you can normally make.

Coralborn Harp (Rare).name: Coralborn Harp (Rare)
Coralborn Harp (Rare).description:
Wondrous item, rare (requires attunement)

Coralborn have two genres of music: diurnal and nocturnal. Diurnal celebrates the reef's colour, community, and biodiversity; it is often uplifting and joyful. Nocturnal illustrates the hunt, when sharks prowl, and the millions of tiny medusozoa that make up the coral feed. Though this harp can play any type of music, the time of day can accentuate its magical capabilities.

Diurnal Dream. As an action during the day, you can play one of the following tunes, targeting one creature that can hear you within 30 feet of you, which must succeed on a DC 15 Wisdom saving throw or suffer the tune's effects as described below. The effect ends at the start of your next turn, unless you immediately use your action that turn to continue playing the tune, which extends the duration until the end of your next turn. You can play a tune uninterrupted for a maximum of 1 minute. Once this property of the item has been used, it can't be used again until the next dawn.

  • Charming Melody. The creature is charmed. The effect ends early if you or any of your allies harm the creature. When the effect ends, the creature knows it was charmed by you.

  • Gentle Lullaby. The creature falls asleep and becomes unconscious. The effect ends early if the creature takes damage or if someone uses an action to shake the creature awake.

  • Mesmerising Canon. The creature is incapacitated, using all its movement to follow you. If it is unable to follow you, or if doing so would harm it, it remains motionless until the effect ends. The effect ends early if the creature takes damage or is ever more than 30 feet from you.

Nocturnal Nightmare. As an action during the night, you strike a dissonant chord that scrapes at the hearing organs and cochlear nerves of all creatures in a 30-foot cone. Each creature in the area must make a DC 15 Constitution saving throw. On a failed save, a creature takes [[/r 4d6]] psychic damage and is frightened of you until the end of your next turn. On a successful save, it takes half as much damage and isn't frightened. After this property has been used, roll a [[/r d4]]. On a 1 or 2, all the small feeding medusozoa retreat back into the coral and this property can't be used again until the next dawn.

Allure (Uncommon).name: Allure (Uncommon)
Allure (Uncommon).description:
Wondrous item, uncommon (requires attunement)

As the saying goes: "Lights on the surface serve a purpose. Lights in the deep lure then reap." This magical headpiece, while not the most attractive, has a certain allure.

While wearing this circlet, you can cast the @Compendium[dnd5e.spells.CAxSzHWizrafT033]{Dancing Lights} cantrip.

Lure. While wearing this circlet, you can use your action to briefly create an alluring pattern of glowing lights around you. Each creature within 10 feet of you who sees the pattern must make a DC 13 Wisdom saving throw. On a failed save, the creature becomes charmed until the start of your next turn. While charmed in this way, the creature is incapacitated and must use all its movement to approach you. If a creature ends its movement within 5 feet of you, it reaches towards your circlet. As a reaction, you can cause the circlet to bite down on the creature, dealing [[/r 1d6]] piercing damage and [[/r 1d6]] poison damage to it. Once this property of the circlet has been used, it can't be used again until the next dawn.

Fashioned from the pearlescent bloodshells of the Scarlet Reef, this weapon of the coralborn is enchanted to be especially hydrodynamic underwater.

Hydrodynamic. Attacking while underwater doesn't impose disadvantage on attack rolls you make with this weapon.

A knuckle duster is a simple melee weapon, usually made of metal or another hard material, worn around the knuckles of one hand. They deal [[/r 1d4]] bludgeoning damage on a hit and have the Attached, Light, and Pugilist properties.

Variant: Spiked Knuckle Dusters. This variant on the knuckleduster has the Adaptable (piercing) property.

Attached. You can't be disarmed of this weapon, but donning or doffing the weapon takes an action. You can use a hand equipped with this weapon to hold items, but can't attack with the weapon while doing so. Additionally, you have disadvantage on attack rolls using other weapons held in a hand equipped with this weapon and on Sleight of Hand checks using the hand that is equipped with this weapon.

Light. A light weapon is small and easy to handle, making it ideal for use when fighting with two weapons.

Pugilist. For creatures that roll a die when they make unarmed strikes (such as the monk or tavern brawler fighter), the size of their damage die is increased by one (maximum 1d12) when they make unarmed strikes with a hand equipped with a weapon that has this property.

Adaptable. This weapon can be used with differing techniques, allowing it to deal different types of damage. A damage type in parentheses appears with the property—when a creature makes a weapon attack with this weapon, it can choose either the weapon's normal damage type or this damage type.

Crosstacean Hand Crossbow (Uncommon).name: Crosstacean Hand Crossbow (Uncommon)
Crosstacean Hand Crossbow (Uncommon).description:
Weapon, uncommon (requires attunement)
Martial weapon, ranged weapon 3 lb.
[[/r 1d6]] piercing - ammunition (30/120 ft.), light, loading

The longevity of lobsters is well known. Using biomancy, this phenomenon can be reversed, resulting in a weapon that can magically age and necrose a target.

This weapon deals an extra [[/r 1d4]] necrotic damage to any target it hits.

The Seize. While holding this weapon, you can use a bonus action to enhance one piece of loaded ammunition with debilitating, arthritic energy that causes the target's joints to seize solid. If the next attack you make with the weapon hits, the target must succeed on a DC 13 Constitution saving throw or become restrained until the end of your next turn. If the target fails by 5 or more, it is paralyzed instead of restrained. After this property has been used, roll a [[/r d6]]. On a 3 or lower, the lobster's colour fades to grey, and this property can't be used again until the next dawn.

Range. A weapon that can be used to make a ranged attack has a range shown in parentheses after the ammunition or thrown property. The range lists two numbers. The first is the weapon's normal range in feet, and the second indicates the weapon's maximum range. When attacking a target beyond normal range, you have disadvantage on the attack roll. You can't attack a target beyond the weapon's long range.

Ammunition. You can use a weapon that has the ammunition property to make a ranged attack only if you have ammunition to fire from the weapon. Each time you attack with the weapon, you expend one piece of ammunition. Drawing the ammunition from a quiver, case, or other container is part of the attack. Loading a one-handed weapon requires a free hand. At the end of the battle, you can recover half your expended ammunition by taking a minute to search the battlefield.

If you use a weapon that has the ammunition property to make a melee attack, you treat the weapon as an improvised weapon. A sling must be loaded to deal any damage when used in this way.

Light. A light weapon is small and easy to handle, making it ideal for use when fighting with two weapons.

Loading. Because of the time required to load this weapon, you can fire only one piece of ammunition from it when you use an action, bonus action, or reaction to fire it, regardless of the number of attacks you can normally make.

Weapon, common
Simple weapon, melee weapon 2 lb.
[[/r 1d6]] slashing - light, thrown (20/60 ft.)

Fashioned from the pearlescent bloodshells of the Scarlet Reef, this weapon of the coralborn is enchanted to be especially hydrodynamic underwater.

Hydrodynamic. Attacking while underwater doesn't impose disadvantage on attack rolls you make with this weapon.

Light. A light weapon is small and easy to handle, making it ideal for use when fighting with two weapons.

Thrown. If a weapon has the thrown property, you can throw the weapon to make a ranged attack. If the weapon is a melee weapon, you use the same ability modifier for that attack roll and damage roll that you would use for a melee attack with the weapon. For example, if you throw a handaxe, you use your Strength, but if you throw a dagger, you can use either your Strength or your Dexterity, since the dagger has the finesse property.

Seashell Revolver (Uncommon).name: Seashell Revolver (Uncommon)
Seashell Revolver (Uncommon).description:
Weapon, uncommon
Firearm, martial weapon, ranged weapon [[/r 1d10]] piercing - ammunition (60/240 ft.), Loud (500), Reload (6)

Fashioned from the pearlescent bloodshells of the Scarlet Reef, this weapon of the coralborn is enchanted to be especially hydrodynamic underwater.

You gain a +1 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with this magic weapon while underwater.

Hydrodynamic. Attacking while underwater doesn't impose disadvantage on attack rolls you make with this weapon.

A small, personal firearm with a rotating barrel and accuracy-enhancing rifling that deals [[/r 1d10]] piercing damage on a hit. It has the Ammunition (range 60/240), Loud (500), Reload (6) properties.

Extra Reloads. More expensive models of magitech firearms have a self-reloading mechanism that harnesses the arcanomagnetic engine to re-cock the weapon. If you wish, you can increase the magazine capacity of a magitech firearm up to a maximum of 6, ensuring that the price increases proportionally. For example, a pistol typically costs 200 gp and has reload (2). If you increased this to reload (6), you would multiply the price by 3 for a new cost of 600 gp.

Range. A weapon that can be used to make a ranged attack has a range shown in parentheses after the ammunition or thrown property. The range lists two numbers. The first is the weapon's normal range in feet, and the second indicates the weapon's maximum range. When attacking a target beyond normal range, you have disadvantage on the attack roll. You can't attack a target beyond the weapon's long range.

Ammunition. You can use a weapon that has the ammunition property to make a ranged attack only if you have ammunition to fire from the weapon. Each time you attack with the weapon, you expend one piece of ammunition. Drawing the ammunition from a quiver, case, or other container is part of the attack. Loading a one-handed weapon requires a free hand. At the end of the battle, you can recover half your expended ammunition by taking a minute to search the battlefield.

If you use a weapon that has the ammunition property to make a melee attack, you treat the weapon as an improvised weapon. A sling must be loaded to deal any damage when used in this way.

Loud (X). The sound of the weapon discharging alerts all hearing creatures within a number of feet as specified by the number in parentheses after the loud property. This range is doubled in echoey locations, such as cave systems, and where sound travels faster, such as underwater.

Reload (X). A limited number of shots, specified by the number in parentheses after the reload property, can be made with this weapon. A character must then reload it using an action.

Tommybows are repeating crossbows that mirror the three types of normal crossbows: hand, heavy, and light. They are composed of vertically-stacked bows upon a crossbow's chassis, an unwieldy arrangement that reduces their effective range in comparison to their crossbow counterparts.

Tommybows replace the loading property of their crossbow counterpart with the reload property. The cost of the item is proportional to the amount of ammunition it can hold (the value in parentheses), with the maximum reload (6) tommybow costing six times its crossbow counterpart's price.

Two-Handed. This weapon requires two hands to use. This property is relevant only when you attack with the weapon, not when you simply hold it.

Sharktooth Longsword (Very Rare).name: Sharktooth Longsword (Very Rare)
Sharktooth Longsword (Very Rare).description:
Weapon, very rare (requires attunement)

Martial weapon, melee weapon 3 lb.
[[/r 1d8]] slashing - versatile ([[/r 1d10]])

Fashioned especially for the Hammerhead Knight, this blade caused its victims to bleed, allowing the knight, with its superior sense of smell, to track a would-be assassin back to its lair.

You gain a +2 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with this magic weapon.

Maim. Once on each of your turns when you hit a creature with an attack roll using this weapon, you can speak its command word, causing its teeth-like protrusions to rip through the target. Roll a [[/r d4]] and consult the following table to determine the effect:

[[/r d4]]Effect
1No additional effect.
2Hamstring. The creature’s speed is reduced to 0 feet until the end of its next turn.
3Rend. The creature has disadvantage on attack rolls until the end of its next turn.
4Sever. If the creature has blood, it begins bleeding for 1 minute. Each time it takes bludgeoning, piercing, or slashing damage while bleeding, it takes an extra [[/r 1d4]] necrotic damage. The target or a creature within reach can use an action to make a DC 16 Wisdom (Medicine) check, stopping the bleeding on a success.

Hydrodynamic. Attacking while underwater doesn't impose disadvantage on attack rolls you make with this weapon.

Versatile. This weapon can be used with one or two hands. A damage value in parentheses appears with the property—the damage when the weapon is used with two hands to make a melee attack.

Flumfpot (Rare).name: Flumfpot (Rare)
Flumfpot (Rare).description:
Wondrous item, rare

Flumfpots are usually found hovering around a corpse. If you can't see the corpse, then it's almost definitely because it's been so long the corpse has disintegrated into dust. This is because a flumfpot is magically enchanted to always follow the last creature whose lips (or other drinking orifice) it touched.

A creature can use its action to pour a potion into an empty flumfpot within its reach.

Mastery and Movement. After a creature touches the flumfpot with its lips, it becomes the flumfpot's master. The flumfpot follows its master around, hovering just over their shoulder. It has a flying speed of 30 feet and a swimming speed of 60 feet. If it is within 5 feet of its master when its master teleports, it teleports with them. Otherwise, it remains in place until touched by another creature's lips. A flumfpot that is prevented from moving will fly towards its master via the most direct route when released.

Send Aid. As a bonus action, you can command the flumfpot to move up to its speed towards a willing or unconscious creature you can see and feed its contents to it.

Filling Flumfpot. An empty flumfpot magically refills itself with a random potion each day at dawn. Roll a [[/r d20]] and consult the following table to determine the potion:

If you use a weapon that has the ammunition property to make a melee attack, you treat the weapon as an improvised weapon. A sling must be loaded to deal any damage when used in this way.

Seashell Hand Crossbow (Common).name: Seashell Hand Crossbow (Common)
Seashell Hand Crossbow (Common).description:
Weapon, common
Martial weapon, ranged weapon 3 lb.
[[/r 1d6]] piercing - ammunition (30/120 ft.), light, loading

Fashioned from the pearlescent bloodshells of the Scarlet Reef, this weapon of the coralborn is enchanted to be especially hydrodynamic underwater.

Hydrodynamic. Attacking while underwater doesn't impose disadvantage on attack rolls you make with this weapon.

Range. A weapon that can be used to make a ranged attack has a range shown in parentheses after the ammunition or thrown property. The range lists two numbers. The first is the weapon's normal range in feet, and the second indicates the weapon's maximum range. When attacking a target beyond normal range, you have disadvantage on the attack roll. You can't attack a target beyond the weapon's long range.

Ammunition. You can use a weapon that has the ammunition property to make a ranged attack only if you have ammunition to fire from the weapon. Each time you attack with the weapon, you expend one piece of ammunition. Drawing the ammunition from a quiver, case, or other container is part of the attack. Loading a one-handed weapon requires a free hand. At the end of the battle, you can recover half your expended ammunition by taking a minute to search the battlefield.

If you use a weapon that has the ammunition property to make a melee attack, you treat the weapon as an improvised weapon. A sling must be loaded to deal any damage when used in this way.

Light. A light weapon is small and easy to handle, making it ideal for use when fighting with two weapons.

Loading. Because of the time required to load this weapon, you can fire only one piece of ammunition from it when you use an action, bonus action, or reaction to fire it, regardless of the number of attacks you can normally make.

Seashell Spear (Common).name: Seashell Spear (Common)
Seashell Spear (Common).description:
Weapon, common
Simple weapon, melee weapon 3 lb.
[[/r 1d6]] piercing - thrown (20/60 ft.), versatile ([[/r 1d8]])

Fashioned from the pearlescent bloodshells of the Scarlet Reef, this weapon of the coralborn is enchanted to be especially hydrodynamic underwater.

Hydrodynamic. Attacking while underwater doesn't impose disadvantage on attack rolls you make with this weapon.

Thrown. If a weapon has the thrown property, you can throw the weapon to make a ranged attack. If the weapon is a melee weapon, you use the same ability modifier for that attack roll and damage roll that you would use for a melee attack with the weapon. For example, if you throw a handaxe, you use your Strength, but if you throw a dagger, you can use either your Strength or your Dexterity, since the dagger has the finesse property.

Versatile. This weapon can be used with one or two hands. A damage value in parentheses appears with the property—the damage when the weapon is used with two hands to make a melee attack.

Seashell Maul (Common).name: Seashell Maul (Common)
Seashell Maul (Common).description:
Weapon, common
Martial weapon, melee weapon 10 lb.
[[/r 2d6]] bludgeoning - heavy, two-handed

Fashioned from the pearlescent bloodshells of the Scarlet Reef, this weapon of the coralborn is enchanted to be especially hydrodynamic underwater.

Hydrodynamic. Attacking while underwater doesn't impose disadvantage on attack rolls you make with this weapon.

Heavy. Creatures that are Small or Tiny have disadvantage on attack rolls with heavy weapons. A heavy weapon's size and bulk make it too large for a Small or Tiny creature to use effectively.

Two-Handed. This weapon requires two hands to use. This property is relevant only when you attack with the weapon, not when you simply hold it.

Crosstacean Heavy Tommybow (Uncommon).name: Crosstacean Heavy Tommybow (Uncommon)
Crosstacean Heavy Tommybow (Uncommon).description:
Weapon, uncommon (requires attunement)
Martial weapon, ranged weapon 18 lb.
[[/r 1d10]] piercing - ammunition (100/200 ft.), heavy, Reload (2), two-handed

The longevity of lobsters is well known. Using biomancy, this phenomenon can be reversed, resulting in a weapon that can magically age and necrose a target.

This weapon deals an extra [[/r 1d4]] necrotic damage to any target it hits.

The Seize. While holding this weapon, you can use a bonus action to enhance one piece of loaded ammunition with debilitating, arthritic energy that causes the target's joints to seize solid. If the next attack you make with the weapon hits, the target must succeed on a DC 13 Constitution saving throw or become restrained until the end of your next turn. If the target fails by 5 or more, it is paralyzed instead of restrained. After this property has been used, roll a [[/r d6]]. On a 3 or lower, the lobster's colour fades to grey, and this property can't be used again until the next dawn.

Tommybows are repeating crossbows that mirror the three types of normal crossbows: hand, heavy, and light. They are composed of vertically-stacked bows upon a crossbow's chassis, an unwieldy arrangement that reduces their effective range in comparison to their crossbow counterparts.

Tommybows replace the loading property of their crossbow counterpart with the reload property. The cost of the item is proportional to the amount of ammunition it can hold (the value in parentheses), with the maximum reload (6) tommybow costing six times its crossbow counterpart's price.

Seashell Rifle (Common).description:
Weapon, common
Firearm, martial weapon, ranged weapon [[/r 1d12]] piercing - ammunition (120/480 ft.), Loud (500), Reload (6), two-handed

Fashioned from the pearlescent bloodshells of the Scarlet Reef, this weapon of the coralborn is enchanted to be especially hydrodynamic underwater.

Hydrodynamic. Attacking while underwater doesn't impose disadvantage on attack rolls you make with this weapon.

The longest range of all the firearms, typically equipped with a multi-bullet magazine, it deals [[/r 1d12]] piercing damage on a hit. It has the Ammunition (range 120/480), Loud (500), Reload (6), and Two-handed properties.

Extra Reloads. More expensive models of magitech firearms have a self-reloading mechanism that harnesses the arcanomagnetic engine to re-cock the weapon. If you wish, you can increase the magazine capacity of a magitech firearm up to a maximum of 6, ensuring that the price increases proportionally. For example, a pistol typically costs 200 gp and has reload (2). If you increased this to reload (6), you would multiply the price by 3 for a new cost of 600 gp.

Range. A weapon that can be used to make a ranged attack has a range shown in parentheses after the ammunition or thrown property. The range lists two numbers. Loud (X). The sound of the weapon discharging alerts all hearing creatures within a number of feet as specified by the number in parentheses after the loud property. This range is doubled in echoey locations, such as cave systems, and where sound travels faster, such as underwater.

Reload (X). A limited number of shots, specified by the number in parentheses after the reload property, can be made with this weapon. A character must then reload it using an action.

Two-Handed. This weapon requires two hands to use. This property is relevant only when you attack with the weapon, not when you simply hold it.

Coral Crusher Club (Uncommon).name: Coral Crusher Club (Uncommon)
Coral Crusher Club (Uncommon).description:
Weapon, uncommon
Simple weapon, melee weapon 2 lb.
[[/r 1d4]] bludgeoning - light

Through biomantic infusions, the coral that comprises this weapon can grow rapidly, quickly replenishing itself under the right conditions. Coralborn have mixed feelings towards such magic weapons. Some believe that it is sacrilege to damage a reef, while others argue that the foes these weapons shred are prevented from doing any harm to anything, including reefs. The jury is still out. These heavy weapons, with their fragile, spiky exteriors, send splinters of coral flying, hurting all creatures within close proximity. Safety glasses are recommended.

Shred. Once on each of your turns when you hit a target with a melee attack using this weapon, you can cause coral shrapnel to burst out. The target and each creature within 5 feet of it must succeed on a DC 13 Dexterity saving throw or take piercing damage equal to one of the weapon's damage dice. You have advantage on this saving throw.

Hydrodynamic. Attacking while underwater doesn't impose disadvantage on attack rolls you make with this weapon.

Light. A light weapon is small and easy to handle, making it ideal for use when fighting with two weapons.

Tidecutter (Legendary).name: Tidecutter (Legendary)
Tidecutter (Legendary).description:
Weapon (@Compendium[dnd5e.items.10ZP2Bu3vnCuYMIB]{Longsword}), legendary (requires attunement)

Martial weapon, melee weapon 500 lb.
[[/r 1d8]] slashing - versatile ([[/r 1d10]])

With the sound of waves crashing violently against a rocky cliff, the sword's blade rushes forth like the tide, inevitable and unstoppable. Not even tempered steel can resist its edge, which slices through obstacles like a hot knife through melted butter.

This item appears to be a sword hilt stylized with tentacles. While grasping the hilt, you can use a bonus action to cause a blade of rushing water to spring forth, or make it disappear. While the blade exists, this magic longsword has the finesse property. If you are proficient with shortswords or longswords, you are proficient with the tidecutter.

You gain a +3 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with this magic weapon.

Water Lash. As an action, you can cause the sword's blade to elongate into a lash and make a melee weapon attack using it against a target within 30 feet of you. On a hit, if the target is a Huge or smaller creature or an object that weighs 10,000 pounds or less, you can pull it up to 25 feet towards you. Gargantuan creatures are only pulled if they fail on a DC 17 Strength saving throw.If the target is a fixed object or a Gargantuan or larger creature, you can pull yourself up to 25 feet towards the target.

Waterborne. When submerged in water, this longsword gains the reach property and the range of the Water Lash property increases to 40 feet.

Hydrodynamic. Attacking while underwater doesn't impose disadvantage on attack rolls you make with this weapon.

Versatile. This weapon can be used with one or two hands. A damage value in parentheses appears with the property—the damage when the weapon is used with two hands to make a melee attack.

Slingshots are simple ranged weapons comprising an elasticated material strung between a Y-frame brace. They deal [[/r 1d6]] bludgeoning damage on a hit and have the Ammunition (range 20/60) and Two-handed properties. They use the same ammunition as slings.

Range. A weapon that can be used to make a ranged attack has a range shown in parentheses after the ammunition or thrown property. The range lists two numbers. The first is the weapon's normal range in feet, and the second indicates the weapon's maximum range. When attacking a target beyond normal range, you have disadvantage on the attack roll. You can't attack a target beyond the weapon's long range.

Ammunition. You can use a weapon that has the ammunition property to make a ranged attack only if you have ammunition to fire from the weapon. Each time you attack with the weapon, you expend one piece of ammunition. Drawing the ammunition from a quiver, case, or other container is part of the attack. Loading a one-handed weapon requires a free hand. At the end of the battle, you can recover half your expended ammunition by taking a minute to search the battlefield.

If you use a weapon that has the ammunition property to make a melee attack, you treat the weapon as an improvised weapon. A sling must be loaded to deal any damage when used in this way.

Two-Handed. This weapon requires two hands to use. This property is relevant only when you attack with the weapon, not when you simply hold it.

Seashell Halberd (Common).name: Seashell Halberd (Common)
Seashell Halberd (Common).description:
Weapon, common
Martial weapon, melee weapon 6 lb.
[[/r 1d10]] slashing - heavy, reach, two-handed

Fashioned from the pearlescent bloodshells of the Scarlet Reef, this weapon of the coralborn is enchanted to be especially hydrodynamic underwater.

Hydrodynamic. Attacking while underwater doesn't impose disadvantage on attack rolls you make with this weapon.

Heavy. Creatures that are Small or Tiny have disadvantage on attack rolls with heavy weapons. A heavy weapon's size and bulk make it too large for a Small or Tiny creature to use effectively.

Reach. This weapon adds 5 feet to your reach when you attack with it. This property also determines your reach for opportunity attacks with a reach weapon.

Two-Handed. This weapon requires two hands to use. This property is relevant only when you attack with the weapon, not when you simply hold it.

Martial weapon, ranged weapon 18 lb.
[[/r 1d10]] piercing - ammunition (100/400 ft.), heavy, loading, two-handed

The longevity of lobsters is well known. Using biomancy, this phenomenon can be reversed, resulting in a weapon that can magically age and necrose a target.

This weapon deals an extra [[/r 1d6]] necrotic damage to any target it hits.

The Seize. While holding this weapon, you can use a bonus action to enhance one piece of loaded ammunition with debilitating, arthritic energy that causes the target's joints to seize solid. If the next attack you make with the weapon hits, the target must succeed on a DC 15 Constitution saving throw or become restrained until the end of your next turn. If the target fails by 5 or more, it is paralyzed instead of restrained. After this property has been used, roll a [[/r d6]]. On a 2 or 1, the lobster's colour fades to grey, and this property can't be used again until the next dawn.

Range. A weapon that can be used to make a ranged attack has a range shown in parentheses after the ammunition or thrown property. The range lists two numbers. Heavy. Creatures that are Small or Tiny have disadvantage on attack rolls with heavy weapons. A heavy weapon's size and bulk make it too large for a Small or Tiny creature to use effectively.

Loading. Because of the time required to load this weapon, you can fire only one piece of ammunition from it when you use an action, bonus action, or reaction to fire it, regardless of the number of attacks you can normally make.

Two-Handed. This weapon requires two hands to use. This property is relevant only when you attack with the weapon, not when you simply hold it.

Hydrodynamic. Attacking while underwater doesn't impose disadvantage on attack rolls you make with this weapon.

Tommybows are repeating crossbows that mirror the three types of normal crossbows: hand, heavy, and light. They are composed of vertically-stacked bows upon a crossbow's chassis, an unwieldy arrangement that reduces their effective range in comparison to their crossbow counterparts.

Tommybows replace the loading property of their crossbow counterpart with the reload property. The cost of the item is proportional to the amount of ammunition it can hold (the value in parentheses), with the maximum reload (6) tommybow costing six times its crossbow counterpart's price.

Fashioned from the pearlescent bloodshells of the Scarlet Reef, this weapon of the coralborn is enchanted to be especially hydrodynamic underwater.

Hydrodynamic. Attacking while underwater doesn't impose disadvantage on attack rolls you make with this weapon.

Thrown. If a weapon has the thrown property, you can throw the weapon to make a ranged attack. If the weapon is a melee weapon, you use the same ability modifier for that attack roll and damage roll that you would use for a melee attack with the weapon. For example, if you throw a handaxe, you use your Strength, but if you throw a dagger, you can use either your Strength or your Dexterity, since the dagger has the finesse property.

Versatile. This weapon can be used with one or two hands. A damage value in parentheses appears with the property—the damage when the weapon is used with two hands to make a melee attack.

Seashell Net (Uncommon).name: Seashell Net (Uncommon)
Seashell Net (Uncommon).description:
Weapon, uncommon
Martial weapon, ranged weapon 3 lb. special, thrown (5/15 ft.)

Fashioned from the pearlescent bloodshells of the Scarlet Reef, this weapon of the coralborn is enchanted to be especially hydrodynamic underwater.

You gain a +1 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with this magic weapon while underwater.

Hydrodynamic. Attacking while underwater doesn't impose disadvantage on attack rolls you make with this weapon.

Special. A Large or smaller creature hit by a net is restrained until it is freed. A net has no effect on creatures that are formless, or creatures that are Huge or larger. A creature can use its action to make a DC 10 Strength check, freeing itself or another creature within its reach on a success. Dealing 5 slashing damage to the net (AC 10) also frees the creature without harming it, ending the effect and destroying the net. When you use an action, bonus action, or reaction to attack with a net, you can make only one attack regardless of the number of attacks you can normally make.

Range. A weapon that can be used to make a ranged attack has a range shown in parentheses after the ammunition or thrown property. The range lists two numbers. For example, if you throw a handaxe, you use your Strength, but if you throw a dagger, you can use either your Strength or your Dexterity, since the dagger has the finesse property.

Cloak of the Cnidaran (Very Rare).name: Cloak of the Cnidaran (Very Rare)
Cloak of the Cnidaran (Very Rare).description:
Wondrous item, very rare (requires attunement)

Made of magical cnidaran shimmerweave, this cloak shifts its hue with the emotions of its attuned wearer. The Deep King's court jester used to wear one such raiment, making his acrobatic and charismatic displays all the more entertaining. While wearing the cloak, you have a swimming speed of 60 feet and can breathe underwater.

Prismatic Shimmer. As an action while wearing this cloak, you can cause it to shimmer in a pleasing and distracting array of colours for 10 minutes. For the duration, you have advantage on Deception, Performance, and Persuasion checks. Once this property of the cloak has been used, it can't be used again until the next dawn.

Nematocyst Fibres. As an action while wearing this cloak, you can cause its fibres to become aggressive for 1 minute. The cloak shimmers in shades of red and mauve, giving you advantage on Intimidation checks against creatures that can see you. As part of the action to activate the fibres, and as an action on subsequent turns, you can cause the cloak's filaments to brush against a creature within 10 feet of you. The target must succeed on a DC 1316 Constitution saving throw or become poisoned until the start of your next turn. Until this poison ends, the target is paralyzed. After a creature succeeds on this saving throw, it is immune to the effects of the cloak for the next 24 hours. Once this property of the cloak has been used, it can't be used again until the next dawn.

Seashell Light Crossbow (Common).description:

Seashell Nunchaku (Common).description:
Weapon, common
Martial weapon, melee weapon [[/r 1d6]] bludgeoning - finesse, special, versatile ([[/r 1d8]])

Fashioned from the pearlescent bloodshells of the Scarlet Reef, this weapon of the coralborn is enchanted to be especially hydrodynamic underwater.

Hydrodynamic. Attacking while underwater doesn't impose disadvantage on attack rolls you make with this weapon.

Nunchuks are martial melee weapons composed of two hard batons, usually wood or metal, connected to one another by a short chain. They have the versatile (1d8), finesse, and special (flourish) properties, and deal 1d6 bludgeoning damage on a hit.

Special: Flourish. When you are wielding the nunchaku in two hands and take the Attack action on your turn, you can attempt to flourish with the weapon immediately before you make your first attack. To flourish, make a DC 13 Dexterity check, adding your proficiency bonus if you are proficient with nunchaku. On a success, you gain a +2 bonus to the first attack roll you make this turn. On a failure, you deal bludgeoning damage to yourself equal to your proficiency bonus and gain no bonus from your flourishes this turn.

Finesse. When making an attack with a finesse weapon, you use your choice of your Strength or Dexterity modifier for the attack and damage rolls. You must use the same modifier for both rolls.

Versatile. This weapon can be used with one or two hands. A damage value in parentheses appears with the property—the damage when the weapon is used with two hands to make a melee attack.

Helmet of the Hammerhead Knight (Rare).name: Helmet of the Hammerhead Knight (Rare)
Helmet of the Hammerhead Knight (Rare).description:
Wondrous item, rare (requires attunement)

A legend of the seven seas spoken of only in hushed tones, the Hammerhead Knight is said to be a strange hybrid of man and shark. Lingering mists of blood in the water are often interpreted as signs of his passage, and though tales invariably describe him vanquishing pirates and scoundrels, most prefer to avoid him... just in case.

Shark Senses. While wearing this helmet, your peripheral vision extends behind you and your sense of smell is enhanced, granting you advantage on initiative rolls and Wisdom (Perception) checks that involve smell. In addition, you can inhale deeply as an action, gaining blindsight to a range of 30 feet until the start of your next turn. This blindsight can only detect a creature that has blood and is below its hit point maximum.

Blood Frenzy. While wearing this helmet, you can cast the blood frenzy spell on yourself. When you do, roll a [[/r d6]]. On a 3 or lower, this property of the helm can't be used again until the next dawn.

Curse. This helmet is cursed with the essence of its former occupant, and becoming attuned to it extends the curse to you. As long as you remain cursed, you are unwilling to remove the helmet. Over the course of a week, you begin to develop shark-like features. First, your skin develops small patches of tough, iridescent scales. Next, your fingers and toes become webbed, and small fins appear on your elbow and neck. Lastly are the teeth. They become a jagged conveyor belt of razors, a natural weapon which you can use to make unarmed strikes. If you hit with it, you deal piercing damage equal to [[/r 1d6]] + your Strength modifier. Once you grow these shark teeth, the curse is complete and you are constantly under the effects of the blood frenzy spell. A remove curse spell or similar magic ends the curse and the effects of the blood frenzy spell, but doesn't undo any changes to your appearance that have already occurred, including the natural weapon.

Seashell Net (Common).description:
